title: About me
text: Hi, My name is McKay Clark. I am 24 and am a student at Brigham Young University Idaho who is trying to figure out what to study that relates to coding and computers. I’m currently looking into software engineering or web development, but I am open to the many other options offered here as well. I love to play guitar, sing, be outside and play video games. I currently work as a sales associate in the men’s department for Dillards in Idaho Falls.

title: Client Report - [Project 0]
text:
__The data that I have illustrated in the scatterplot and table bellow explores the relationship between the highway miles per gallon and the engine displacement which is the amount of air moved by the car’s cylinders wether that be in or out of it. I found a trend where, the lower the engine displacement, the higher the miles per gallon were on the highways. Towards the end of the chart, I noticed a few outliers with some of the higher displacement engines having I higher value of miles per gallon than their counterparts. Something like this may suggest that the chart may continue in an upward trend._


Show the code
mpg = pd.read_csv("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/byuidatascience/data4python4ds/master/data-raw/mpg/mpg.csv")


I believe I have everything running smoothly. I uninstalled python 3.12 and reinstalled python 3.11.7 to be safe. I have no other questions at this time.

__The data that I have illustrated in the scatterplot and table bellow explores the relationship between the highway miles per gallon and the engine displacement which is the amount of air moved by the car’s cylinders wether that be in or out of it. I found a trend where, the lower the engine displacement, the higher the miles per gallon were on the highways. Towards the end of the chart, I noticed a few outliers with some of the higher displacement engines having I higher value of miles per gallon than their counterparts. Something like this may suggest that the chart may continue in an upward trend._


Show the code
mpg = pd.read_csv("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/byuidatascience/data4python4ds/master/data-raw/mpg/mpg.csv")


I believe I have everything running smoothly. I uninstalled python 3.12 and reinstalled python 3.11.7 to be safe. I have no other questions at this time.

title: Client Report - [Project 0]
text:
Manufacturer Scatterplot
It took a lot of hopping from source to source in the reading but it came to me slowly but surely. Below includes the scatterplot created in plotly which replicates the scatterplot in textbook 3.2.2.
::: {#cell-Q2 chart .cell execution_count=3}

plot example
chart = px.scatter(mpg.head(200),
    x="displ", 
    y="hwy",
    color="manufacturer"
)
chart.show()


                                                
Scatterplot

:::

title: Client Report - [Project 0]
text:
Manufacturer Markdown Table
The markdown table took quite a while for me to figure out how to render it. I needed to install tabulate to have my code generate the table. My syntax initially to install it was incorrect. after finding the correct synax I was able to move forward. The markdown table that was generated featured five of the same audi model a4 from different years. I found that the audi’s that were from earlier years like 1999 had a lower highway miles per gallon than their counterparts from 2008. This may suggest that as time has moved forward the engine displacement has gotten lower and more efficient.


table
print(mpg
  .head(5)
  .filter(["manufacturer", "model","year", "hwy"])
  .to_markdown(index=False))


| manufacturer   | model   |   year |   hwy |
|:---------------|:--------|-------:|------:|
| audi           | a4      |   1999 |    29 |
| audi           | a4      |   1999 |    29 |
| audi           | a4      |   2008 |    31 |
| audi           | a4      |   2008 |    30 |
| audi           | a4      |   1999 |    26 |

title: Client Report - [Project 1]
text:
For my research I decided to look at a data set with names and pose a few questions to the data. I first looked at my name and how it was used both in my birth year and in the rest of it’s usage history to see if my name was used more or less before and after that year. I then decided to look at the name “Brittany”‘s’ usage to determine what age I would guess a person this year would most likely be if they had that name. Next, I studied the trends in name usage for Mary, Martha, Peter, and Paul to see what trends those names followed from 1920 - 2000. Finally I compared main character names and their usages in history to the release date of the movie to see if there was any correlation between the two.


Read and format project data
df = pd.read_csv("https://github.com/byuidatascience/data4names/raw/master/data-raw/names_year/names_year.csv")


Highlight the Questions and Tasks

title: Client Report - [Project 1]
text:
For my research I decided to look at a data set with names and pose a few questions to the data. I first looked at my name and how it was used both in my birth year and in the rest of it’s usage history to see if my name was used more or less before and after that year. I then decided to look at the name “Brittany”‘s’ usage to determine what age I would guess a person this year would most likely be if they had that name. Next, I studied the trends in name usage for Mary, Martha, Peter, and Paul to see what trends those names followed from 1920 - 2000. Finally I compared main character names and their usages in history to the release date of the movie to see if there was any correlation between the two.

title: Client Report - [Project 1]
text:
My Name
How does your name at your birth year compare to its use historically?
Before my birth year, we see that the common usage of my name starts in 1976 and from that time till 1985 the total number of babies born with that name stays roughly between 5 and 8 per year with one exception in 1977 with 0 reported. From there we see a sharp upward trend which ends in a peak usage of 72 total in 1995. from there we see it dip down to 39 in 1998 and 1999. After my birth year, the name usage shows a downward trend with a spike of usage every few years.


Read and format data
df = pd.read_csv("https://github.com/byuidatascience/data4names/raw/master/data-raw/names_year/names_year.csv").query("name == 'Mckay'")


::: {#cell-Q1 chart .cell execution_count=4}

plot example
chart = px.bar(df.head(200),
    x="year", 
    y="Total",
    color="name",
    title="Total Number of Babies per Year Named 'Mckay'"
)
chart.add_annotation(x=1999, y=39,
            text="My birth year",
            showarrow=True,
            arrowhead=1)
chart.add_annotation(x=1976, y=8,
            text="Name starts to be used more frequently",
            showarrow=False,
            yshift=10)
chart.add_annotation(x=1986, y=15,
            text="Name usage shows upward trend",
            showarrow=False,
            yshift=10)
chart.add_annotation(x=1995, y=72,
            text="Peak usage of name",
            showarrow=False,
            yshift=10)
chart.add_annotation(x=2002, y=54,
            text="Name usage shows downward trend",
            showarrow=False,
            yshift=10)
chart.show()


                                                

:::

title: Client Report - [Project 1]
text:
Brittany
If you talked to someone named Brittany on the phone, what is your guess of his or her age? What ages would you not guess?
If I were to go off of a random guess, I would say they would probably be in their 30s right now. Based off of the chart of name usage per year, my guess is accurate because it is more likely someone named Brittany will be in their 30s. I would probably not guess anyone in their 20s or lower or anyone in their 40s or higher


Read and format data
df = pd.read_csv("https://github.com/byuidatascience/data4names/raw/master/data-raw/names_year/names_year.csv").query("name == 'Brittany'")


::: {#cell-Q2 chart .cell execution_count=6}

plot example
chart = px.bar(df.head(200),
    x="year", 
    y="Total",
    color="name",
    title="Total Number of Babies per Year Named 'Brittany'"
)
chart.add_annotation(x=1986, y=17856.5,
    text="Start of Brittany in their 30s / My guess",
    showarrow=True,
    arrowhead=1)

chart.add_annotation(x=1976, y=304,
    text="Brittany in 20s. Would not guess this or lower",
    showarrow=True,
    arrowhead=1)

chart.add_annotation(x=1996, y=13796,
    text="Brittany in 40s. Would not guess this or higher",
    showarrow=True,
    arrowhead=1)
chart.show()


                                                

:::

title: Client Report - [Project 1]
text:
Christian Names
Mary, Martha, Peter, and Paul are all Christian names. From 1920 - 2000, compare the name usage of each of the four names. What trends do you notice?
The biggest thing I noticed right off the bat is that the name ‘Mary’ has by far the highest usage from 1920 all the way until 1968 where we see ‘Paul’ overtake. ‘Mary’ then makes a ressurgance in between 1988 and 1989 and becomes, once again, the most used name on through 2000. ‘Paul’, throughout the years is always higher in usage than both ‘Martha’ and ‘Peter’ and only being supassed by ‘Mary’ for the majority of the time. ‘Martha’ stays above ‘Peter’ and below ‘Paul’ from 1920 till 1953 where it dips below ‘Peter’ securing it’s spot as the least used name of the bunch overall. ‘Peter’ starts off as the lowest used name from 1920 until 1953 where it surpasses ‘Martha’. From then on it remains above ‘Martha’ and becomes the second lowest used name overall. Something interesting to note is that in all of the names, I noticed the beginning of an upward trend in all of them around 1936 with ‘Peter’ and ‘Paul’ being the only ones that started the upward trend a few years earlier. We also see a drastic fall for ‘Mary’, ‘Paul’, and ‘Peter’ between the years of 1950 and 1976. ‘Martha’, for whatever reason, started this trend earlier in 1952.


Read and format data
df = pd.read_csv("https://github.com/byuidatascience/data4names/raw/master/data-raw/names_year/names_year.csv").query("name in ['Peter','Paul','Mary','Martha'] & year >= 1920 & year <=2000")


::: {#cell-Q3 chart .cell execution_count=8}

plot example
chart = px.line(df.head(1000),
    x="year", 
    y="Total",
    color="name",
    title="Historical Usage of 'Mary', 'Martha', 'Peter', and 'Paul'"
)
chart.add_annotation(x=1950, y=53791,
    text="Peak of Usage: Mary",
    showarrow=True,
    arrowhead=1)

chart.add_annotation(x=1954, y=25662.5,
    text="Peak of Usage: Paul",
    showarrow=True,
    arrowhead=1)

chart.add_annotation(x=1947, y=10651,
    text="Peak of Usage: Martha",
    showarrow=True,
    arrowhead=1)

chart.add_annotation(x=1956, y=11321,
    text="Peak of Usage: Peter",
    showarrow=True,
    arrowhead=1)

chart.add_annotation(x=2000, y=6184,
    text="Lowest Usage: Mary",
    showarrow=True,
    arrowhead=1)

chart.add_annotation(x=2000, y=3786,
    text="Lowest Usage: Paul",
    showarrow=True,
    arrowhead=1)

chart.add_annotation(x=1932, y=2694.5,
    text="Lowest Usage: Peter",
    showarrow=True,
    arrowhead=1)

chart.add_annotation(x=1999, y=693,
    text="Lowest Usage: Martha",
    showarrow=True,
    arrowhead=1)
chart.show()


                                                

:::

title: Client Report - [Project 1]
text:
Movie Names
Think of a unique name from a famous movie. Plot the usage of that name and see how changes line up with the movie release. Does it look like the movie had an effect on usage?
_I decided to plot the usages of four names: Flynn, Tony, Elsa, and Jack. These are the names of the main characters in Tangled, Pirates of the Caribbean, Frozen, and Iron-Man respectively. I plotted them so I could see if there was any correltion between usage, and the years those movies were released. From what I could see from the data, There was a sharp rise in usage of the name Jack a year after the Pirates movie came out. This one is tough because it seems like there wasn’t a sharp increase in usage until about a year after it came out. I could attribute the usage spike to the movie’s release but I’m not 100% sure. With Elsa, and Flynn, We see a sharp spike in usage after their movies were released suggesting that the movies did cause that spike. As for Tony, we actually see a downward trend start a few years before the Iron-Man movie released. It is hard to determine wether the movie had a significant impact on that name’s usage.


Read and format data
df = pd.read_csv("https://github.com/byuidatascience/data4names/raw/master/data-raw/names_year/names_year.csv").query("name in ['Flynn','Jack','Elsa','Tony']")


::: {#cell-Q4 chart .cell execution_count=10}

plot example
chart = px.line(df.head(1000),
    x="year", 
    y="Total",
    color="name",
    title="Historical Usage of 'Flynn', 'Jack', 'Elsa', and 'Tony'"
)

chart.add_annotation(x=2003, y=9316,
    text="Pirates of the Caribbean released", #|We see a 232 usage increase from 2003 to 2004 after pirates 1. We see a much bigger differance in from 2004 to 2005.
    showarrow=True,
    arrowhead=1)

chart.add_annotation(x=2010, y=24,
    text="Tangled released", #| See a differance of 129 for the next year
    showarrow=True,
    arrowhead=1)

chart.add_annotation(x=2013, y=525,
    text="Frozen released", #| Differance of 580 next year
    showarrow=True,
    arrowhead=1)

chart.add_annotation(x=2008, y=853,
    text="Iron-Man released", #| Down 77 next year
    showarrow=True,
    arrowhead=1)

chart.show()


                                                

:::
